It's about the journey, not the destination. The ultra late-game of Necesse is characterized by an endless stream of boss fights against bosses you've already fought, just with boosted stats (barring a handful of new bosses in unique zones who then become part of the repeat-with-boosted-stats roster). I may or may not see the game through to the final boss, because the reward at this stage is just boosted stats on my own equipment.

But that doesn't put me off of recommending it. It just feels like I've hit the "infinite mode" at the end of the game (though I know it's not infinite, I'd estimate the ultra lategame provides about as much gameplay as the rest of the game put together, but missing a lot of the variety).

All the reviews compare this game favorably to other popular games, I'll try to give some details on why those favorable comparisons get drawn. It's in the little details. Like the forge, operating the same as a furnace in minecraft or other games, has two slots by default for smelting. It only smelts one thing at a time, but it smelts the higher-tier ore into bars first, then smelts the lower-tier ore, and it has two output slots so it can go automatically. This prevents you having the "wall of furnaces" so common in this kind of game, in my wife and I's MP game, we've gotten to the end of the game using two forges the whole way through. It lets you build a smithy that actually looks like a smithy.

And that's another great thing about the game. The decorations. They really let you dress up your base so it feels lived-in. Characters' mood is improved by having a well-decorated bedroom, and your mages enchanting chances are better if they're happier, so you're rewarded for decorating. And it's easy to do, too! Slap down a table and a couple of chairs, craft a decoration for on the table, a few potted plants, and you've got a lively looking bedroom in a few seconds.

A caveat: We play on Adventure (the second-easiest) difficulty, with item drop on death and food spoilage turned off. Neither of us is a big fan of padding playtime with increased difficulty. And at least for us, this is the perfect difficulty. We still die occasionally in fights, but we never get stuck. So my advice if you're reading reviews and put off by some of them mentioning hard bosses: You can change the difficulty midgame, and have nothing to prove to anyone, just tune the difficulty to where you feel comfortable. There aren't even achievements related to difficulty.

Another great thing to mention is how easy it is to feed your settlers. I'll remind you again: We play with food spoilage turned off, so I'm unfamiliar with how the icebox works, but compared to Rimworld, where the primary difficulty with large bases lies in reliably feeding your colonists, some quick back of the envelope math is all it took to have an infinite food supply going. We have about 45 settlers in our settlement, and I planted 40 of each crop once we had them all available (conveniently, the storage boxes show "x unknown items" in the categories, so I knew how many types of seeds there were before we had access to them and could prepare the farmland ahead of time), we had 40 settlers at the time. Settlers automatically replant crops when they harvest them, and every settler is capable of farming and equally competent at it, so combined with a few cooking stations (each workstation can only hold 10 automatic recipes for settlers to craft, which annoyed me when I first ran into it but then I realized naturally makes your base look larger when it [i]should[/i] look larger), we have our settlers automatically crafting every variety of "gourmet" quality food. Even before we had the high-tier cooking crafting table, feeding our colonists was never an issue. Nothing is wasted in this game, if you break a blueberry bush, you get a blueberry bush sapling, 100% of the time. So just relocate some blueberry bushes near your housing in the early game and your settlers will be contentedly eating "simple" quality blueberries all day until you can sort out your production lines.

I saw a negative review that mentioned the settlement storage settings were confusing. I'm biased coming from 100s of hours of Rimworld, but I found it all fairly intuitive. The kinds of problems you run into with the storage are the same you run into with rimworld, you set a list of allowed things and a priority for the container, so if you forget about a chest on the other side of your base that allows the same things as the one you're looking at, you might be scratching your head wondering where the stuff you're looking for is. But this same system has copy/paste so you can delete a storage and remake it with the same settings instantly if you find a new container you like the aesthetic of more, and you can set a limit to how many stacks of each item are in a container, preventing a "drops" storage from filling up with 10000 bones. In the midgame, you unlock a shipping container you can send your colonists on trading missions to sell the contents of, and this is also an option for "settlement storage" that you can buy extra copies of. Our base has a shipping container set to lowest priority, all types of seeds, so after filling a couple chests with enough seeds to feed an apocalypse, the extras automatically get sold and donated to the village fund for mining trips. Which that's a whole 'nother fun thing, the mid-game mission board lets you send colonists on mining trips automatically, using coins from settlement storage chests. Combined with automatic crafting at the forges and anvils (remember to actually set the recipes, and for goodness sake avoid my mistake and check that it's set to "do x times" not "do until x", lest you craft 20 more helmets than you intended to because it doesn't count equipped items), you can easily re-equip your whole base with just a few directions.

The only downsides to this game are the fact that it leaves you wanting [i]more[/i]. More variety, more to explore, more for your villagers to do. But that isn't to say there isn't a lot there. There really is. I'd estimate we got a solid 50 hours of gameplay each out of the game before we hit the endgame boss grind (so-called "incursions"). Someone playing on a higher difficulty would certainly get more time out of the game before reaching the end. Personally, I don't believe games should offer or try to offer "infinite content/replayability", I think it leads to bland games. I enjoy the experience of "running out of game", after an appropriate length of time of course. Games that go on forever give me a sort of stress because I'm a completionist. This game hits the perfect note of having just barely too much for me to feel like I can do it all (the "collect every item" achievement sounds perfectly impossible, if that makes sense), while still being something I can finish to my satisfaction without devoting my life to it. Definitely my game of the year for 2025.

 This game also have an automation mechanic, where you can, for an example, send Miners to collect ores for you, Anglers to catch an specific kind of fish you need or Explorers to bring resources/acessories from a specific biome. They can also organize the chests for you, which for me is one of the absolute BEST features of this game!

 The progression is linear and felt very satisfying. Essencially you have different biomes and you'll progress through them, every biome has new ores, materials, ingredients and a boss that you can farm to upgrade your gear and keep up with the difficulty, pretty normal stuff.  You can also have your settlers follow you so you can have a party to explore, but be aware that the bosses will have more health the more settlers you bring.
 
 The settlement part for me is where this game truly shines. Managing your colony the way you like, deciding who does what, where they live, what they'll eat, making new houses, decorating them and making everything look nice, it all felt so relaxing, i was always looking foward to having to expand the village and make some new houses for the new settlers, never felt like a chore, which in some games, for me it was.

Necesse feels very similar to Terraria in terms of progression, and is superior to Core Keeper in practically every way except graphics. It's a game about mining, upgrading gear, base building and light colony simulation. There's a huge overworld which is connected to an underworld (and an under underworld), and you can move between the two freely. 2D combat is decent, with 4 different combat styles. There's a massive ton of decorative elements and structural materials for base building, and exploration is really rewarding.

[b]Pros[/b]
- The entire world has an above and below - and you can create ladders between the two anywhere
- There are different trees that all drop specific kinds of wood, rather than just "wood" and they all have their own furniture
- Has craft from nearby chests, and quick stack to nearby chests
- Handmade dungeons to explore
- In addition to the mix of Core Keeper / Terraria gameplay, you can also create settlements, hire villagers, create bedrooms and crafting rooms, and create zones for them to work in, with priorities
- Way more content than Core Keeper
- Lots of different gear sets and crafting materials

[b]Cons[/b]
- I hate character movement with acceleration
- In Core Keeper, if you explore the map while you've got an item on that lights up an area, it uncovers the map. Here, the map only uncovers if you put torches down, which makes the items that light up a lot less fun as you still have to use torches.

A super immersive world with a really solid progression system. Nothing ever feels like a chore, and watching your villagers work in the town you built, which grows alongside your own progress, honestly puts a smile on your face. Every time you think you‚Äôre done, the game surprises you with a new system or an area hiding a ton of fresh content.

[b] Terraria is famous for its combat and bosses. Here, well, according to the meme ‚ÄúTerraria at home‚Äù. [/b]

Despite the truly numerous options for armor and trinkets, classic styles such as warrior, marksman, mage, and summoner can be really disappointing. The bosses in this game are fast and rarely find themselves in a static phase that should be a window of opportunity for shooters and warriors to deal DPS. Of all the bosses (13), only six were fair to the warrior class in my opinion, while the rest favored mages and summoners for one simple reason: almost every boss (except for the witch) is bullet hell. We have about 100 trinekts, which is quite a lot, but what's the point if many of them are just there for the sake of it and don't make sense. Necesse is a top-down Terraria-like. While at a glance it might seem more similar to Core Keeper, it has a lot in common with Terraria that doesn't apply to Core Keeper, so I think it's important to point out the relation to Terraria even if it visually looks like Core Keeper.

This was the first game in a while I played with a keyboard and mouse instead of a controller. I used a Pinky4 keyboard and a Ploopy Classic Trackball mouse. I had researched the game for a few days before starting it and many people mentioned the controls being a bit bad on controller, particularly for the menu navigation and Settlement management aspects, though some say controller is fine for combat. Maybe with a handheld Steam Deck or Steam Controller it'd play okay.

Necesse had me hooked within the first 3-6 hours or so. Once you get a handle on the controls and some of the basic stuff you'll be doing a lot of (mine ore, fight boss, repeat, etc.) it's easy to get into a nice flow. The soundtrack is pretty good and you can find in-game vinyls for most (all?) of the BGM and then override what you hear playing back at your base, or even on the go if you get a portable player.

You have hunger to manage for both you and your Settlers. Food satiates your hunger and also buffs some stats. You can only have the buffs from one food item at once, and whatever you eat last is what "wins". Higher tier food tends to keep you full longer and have better buffs, but it will spoil faster. For your Settlers, variety of food matters for their Happiness stat. You'll ideally want to automatically be crafting a variety of Gourmet food items to get the best Happiness bonus from food.

Speaking of automation, that's the main point of your Settlers. What would probably be done with machines in another game is done with slav- I mean Settlers in this game, a bit like how Senkuu outsources his labor in Dr. Stone. Settlers come in different varieties. There is the basic Villager that can only do the same 4 jobs most types can do, and then there are specialists like the Angler who can buy/sell certain items and can do other kinds of work. While it may be tempting to ignore the Settler system if you're coming from a game like Terraria where you do everything by hand, I would strongly encourage you to learn it and use it. It goes from "ugh they keep moving my items, this is so annoying to deal with" to "oh okay this is pretty nice now that I'm figuring out the chest rules and stuff" and later "wow that final boss was way too hard, it would probably be impossible to beat without my army of 30+ Settlers assisting me in battle". That's right, you can take them into battle. This is a very cool mechanic and makes the game feel more like multiplayer even in singleplayer. There is a special type of Settler known as the Guard whose main purpose is basically to go into battle with you, but you can take the other types with you as well. The main reason to prioritize Guards is probably just that they can't do much work otherwise, just move items around, not farm or anything.

Necesse seems to encourage a lot of JIT (just in time) production, for better or worse. I touched on the spoiled food thing earlier. Basically, you might see you have the ingredients to make a whole stack of Fried Chicken, so you do it. Now you'll be eating well, and so will your Settlers, right? Well, this is satiating stuff, and it spoils in 2 hours. Most likely it'll go bad before you can possibly use it all up. You can make Spoiled Food into Fertilizer, but generally you want to avoid letting too much food spoil. So you end up setting max amounts of each food type to be made/stored that aren't much more than the # of Settlers you have, and then maybe automate the selling of the rest via Shipping Chests. There is a lot of micromanagement of the chest rules while you're figuring stuff out, and they can be annoying, but it does work well once you have it all in place. An example of an annoyance is you see swords are appearing in your ores/bars chest for some reason and you don't want them there, so you disallow them in the settings, but then it turns out they were allowed in 1 or 2 other chests and your Settlers keep moving them to the next one until you've properly banished the item from them all. Automated selling is also a bit risky as they may try to sell a nice item you don't want them to, and if you aren't manually checking your Shipping Chests, you can say goodbye to that cool sword you forgot you had. If you do wanna hoard random cool stuff without it being moved or sold, you can have chests outside the "network" so that the Settlers can't touch them.

I was able to get all the achievements in this game after around 120 hours or so. Complete Collector was the last one I got. You may want to start on it early if you're also going for all the achievements. Specifically, farm pigs to make the Majestic Pig Statue ASAP, dig up every type of floor and wall you see, pick up every type of furniture you see. Don't leave new items on the ground. As long as it's passed through your hands (inventory) briefly, it counts. You can also enable a tracker for the achievement and view a list of items you haven't found yet, although I wouldn't enable this until you're done with most other stuff in the game since it takes up a lot of screen real estate.

A few of the bosses in this game struck me as "bullshit hard", but usually changing up my build, using more buffs, taking more Settlers with me, or improving the gear of my Settlers was enough to get unstuck eventually. I played the whole game on the default difficulty and never turned it up or down. I have read comments from people taking more tries than me to beat certain bosses, so I would say I was at least somewhat skilled at the game, meaning you may have even more trouble than me. If you are sensitive to difficult/unbalanced games (after 100%ing the game I think I can safely say they could tone down some things without it just being considered a skill issue) you may want to steer clear or at least play on a lower difficulty (or just turn it down when you get stuck).

I hit one extremely nasty bug near the end of my run that I think needs to be noted. I loaded up my world and noticed almost all my Settlers had vanished, along with their expensive equipment I'd given them. I had 6 Settlers instead of 32. No idea what caused this. Luckily the game takes automated save backups. I loaded the previous day's, still gone, repeat a few times, 4 or 5 days back in time they were all there again. I finished my run on that restored save. Unfortunately restored saves are treated like new worlds and my map was blank and unexplored again. This would probably be fixable by the Cartographer Table, but... it's currently broken and disabled. Quite the nasty combo of issues. At least I knew my map well enough to get around and I was almost done with the game by this point. I would not have been able to continue beating the final boss without my Settlers and would not have been able to get the last of the achievements, so I consider this a game-breaking issue and extremely serious. Almost enough to make me not recommend the game, but the dev seems active and he seems to care about the players, so I think it'll get sorted out. Plus, I played over 100 hours before I ever hit the issue. I'd say just check your Settler count when quitting out and when loading back in, and roll back ASAP if something is fishy.

Overall I enjoyed the game a lot and it kept me entertained for the whole month of November. This is one of the rare heavily Terraria-inspired games that actually manages to scratch the same itch, and even improve upon Terraria in some ways instead of trying to mix in its own thing and failing at it. The settlement system is genius, as it allows you to automate parts of the gameplay loop you don't like while focusing on the parts you do like, while also feeling like a natural expansion on Terraria's NPC system. For me, I am not a fan of farming, chopping trees, and sorting my chests, so assigning them to my settlers was a godsend while I went off to enjoy spelunking and getting loot from the caves below.

Spelunking is great fun in the first half of the game. The caverns are spacious and give you a lot of movement room to fight enemies, and you rarely need to dig long tunnels to reach more caverns. Every biome has the usual basic melee and ranged enemies, but mix in unique enemy types and hazards to keep you on your toes. The bosses are also a lot of fun and have good variety.

Unfortunately, I think that the game stumbles in some major areas. You're going to see a pattern here.

Because light blocks off enemy spawns, dying outside of boss fights means absolutely nothing, since you can casually walk back over to pick up your stuff without any pushback from enemies. Terraria makes it significantly harder to block enemy spawns to the point where it's not worth doing, so in that game you have to fight enemies to get back to where you died. The only thing you can do to make death actually mean something is to enable permadeath, which I'd rather not do in a game that can take 20+ hours to finish. I modded the game to allow enemies in caves to spawn in light, and found it much better for it.

Being able to place ladders anywhere to go underground seems like a great idea in theory, but it results in them being hilariously overpowered. The surface has no real threats to you, even at night, so you have a cheap craftable item that lets you essentially teleport to wherever you want underground, making it too effortless to sequence break and undermine the whole spelunking aspect of the game. I modded ladders to be static objects that I can't craft, and must use the starting house and nearby villages to go underground. This forces me to actually interface with the caves. (Deep ladders are still craftable and placeable, but I restricted them to only be placeable near normal ladders.)

Cavelings (think of them as reverse mimics) and certain enemies dropping ores encourage grinding to get the gear you need to progress instead of exploration. Certain boss arenas can be a pain to locate since biomes don't always spawn them. The Portal Flask you can get late into the game kills all sense of danger even more than enemy-blocking light does, since you can place an instant fast travel point literally wherever you want for free. It can be annoying to die to a boss multiple times since it means grinding for more of its summon item each time you fail, when I'd rather just immediately retry the boss from the beginning of the fight, since restarting the fight already has enough weight on failure (although to be fair, Terraria has the same problem). There are two enemy types in the second half of the game that look exactly the same but must be treated differently in combat because of one being melee and the other being ranged, making them obnoxious to fight. Of course, I fixed all of these issues with modding.

Basically, this game reaches similar highs to Terraria for me, but only after I tweaked a bunch of stuff with mods. If it wasn't for the game being so easily moddable due to it being written in Java, I would've dropped it a long time ago. It also helps that most of my complaints with the game only require some small tweaking to fix.

There is one thing that isn't easily fixable, though. I am not a fan of the second half of the game, the Deep Caves. It throws what I liked about the first half of the game out the window with overly cramped cave systems that require ridiculous amounts of digging to reach more caves, practically begging you to abuse the "place ladders wherever you want" mechanic to get anywhere (which is just not a fun way to go spelunking and why I modded it out), and doesn't provide enough room to fight the much harder enemies without spending a ridiculous amount of money on dynamite. What was so enjoyable about the normal caves was all the open space and natural interconnecting tunnels making it more about exploration than digging everywhere and blowing up walls. Modding deep cave generation to be like the normal cave generation is going to be much harder than the other stuff I fixed, but if someone can pull it off it would save the second half of the game for me.

To summarize my review, Necesse is the closest I have seen a game be to Terraria's quality in this genre, but it misses the mark in some key areas. Thankfully I have the programming knowledge to fix most of these issues myself, but for others it's a cautious recommendation.

EDIT: This review doesn't go over the endgame incursions simply because I am not interested in them. The rest of the game already gave me my fill by the time I reached them.

A Perfect Blend of Your Favorite Games
If you love Stardew Valley, Terraria, Minecraft, and RimWorld, Necesse is the game you didn't know you needed. It masterfully combines the best elements from each: the cozy progression of Stardew, the exploration and combat of Terraria andMinecraft, and the colony management of RimWorld.
I've been playing since before the 1.0 release, and the improvements have been incredible. The developers have significantly enhanced replayability, added many new items, and revised the map to be seamless between regions providing a endless world to explore and colonize. The 1.0 release wasn't just a milestone, it really improved the depth and my enjoyment of exploring without loading times.
Whether you're building your settlement, exploring dangerous dungeons, managing colonists, building traps for npc raids or playing with friends, Necesse offers that "just one more hour" addictiveness that makes great games unforgettable. Highly recommended for fans of any of the games mentioned above. As of the time of writing this have over 60 hours in and many more to come. One of the best values I have come by in some time. If you are just looking to relax or just enjoy making your villagers doing all your chores and day to day grinding around the settlement, I would recommend giving this title a shot.

Love this game. I'm in the end game now, and realize how much more there is to play and unlock. This is 1.0, and I would like to see more depth in the future in regards to exploration and objectives in the future. However, the colony management leans more towards cozy, which is what I wanted based on the rest of the gameplay. This is not the kind of game I want to micro manage colonists or have to spend countless hours farming, raising livestock, etc. They do a really good job of balancing going out for loot and utilizing different colonists or in-game features to reduce grind so you can focus on fun.

This is where I would like to see more depth. Because the game actually has built in options to allow you to focus on playing the game and having more fun, I'd like to see more reason to explore this infinite world (and the underground). You can basically play through the game and only explore maybe 2 minutes in each direction in the overworld. There are really neat generated houses/towns in different biomes, but they're more of a novelty that wears off quickly because it doesn't add much. The underground is better at rewarding exploration, but I do see some room for improvement (mini-bosses, etc.). 

Crafting is made easy to understand, and there are so many options at 1.0 if decorating is your bag. Really nice to see with the focus on building your own town/colony with NPCs to live and work in. The gameplay loop is very rewarding from explore, loot, craft/upgrade, fight bosses. The options for building your character are vast and allow you to not only use your preferred playstyle, but allows you to explore multiple options in that playstyle. End game does a fantastic job of making the weapons and armor you liked but have progressed past viable again, expanding your options even further. Not sure I can compare it to another game, it was very surprising and welcome, and I'd love to see other games play with the idea in similar ways.

TL;DR: This game is a lot of fun, puts a lot of effort into its systems in fresh ways that are focused on enjoyment of the game. It has a cozy/casual feel while still challenging enough to warrant continuing to progress and build. The game has great breadth, and could use some more depth in exploration/progression. Can't wait to see what future updates bring!

Practically a Terraria clone sprinkled with a "RimWorld/Dwarf Fortress"-style settlement management. The caveat is that is takes the worst from the both worlds.

I will start with the latter part. You can recruit/find various settlers and assign several different work orders to them like managing a forest, animal handling or farming. It's one to one from the RimWorld, with zones, work orders, priorities and bedroom assignments. And that's it. You have what basically is a bunch of one-dimensional slaves to haul and craft. Borrowed diet and grades of meals from RimWorld baffle me the most. This is in-game automation of menial tasks which become irrelevant and self-serving several hours into the game.
Speaking of automation, all crafting orders have to be done manually. No strategic bird-view of RimWorld, where the whole settlement is at your fingertips. You can assign a storage or a workstation to the settlement, but still you need to haul your slow avatar to the workbench or anvil to make "do X thing Y times" orders.

And the former part. The similarities border on blatant copying. Where do I start? Characters and their inventories separate from the world, acting as a save files? Running around, breaking stuff to loot cave systems and different biomes? Equipment modifiers capped at exactly 4%? Tool progression through better ores and loot? Don't get me wrong, none of these are bad things in themselves, or a excuse to throw tantrum about how "Terraria did it first so no one else should be allowed to implement features this way". But when I take take every little bit that makes this game and look at them as a system, I can't see anything other than Terraria. The only difference is that it is top-down rather than sidescroll.
Oh wait, no. There is another one. It is worse in every way. Yes, Terraria has 10+ more years since release compared to this game, which got a 1.0 version a month ago (at the moment of writing this review). Yet, considering how one can see the primary inspiration this game has in every pixel, why not borrow something more important? Fluid controls with shortcuts. Biome-specific loot tables for chests. More interesting enemies rather than hordes of bullet-spongy shamblers who do nothing but waste your health, ammo and, most importantly, your time (that's because they don't drop anything 4 times out of 5).

I did want to give this game as much of a chance as I could, so I've reached the endgame, done a few tablets (their version of maps from path of exile) and I am quite bored unfortunately. The game suffers from some design decisions I'm not a big fan of personally.

So the game is a mix between core keeper, terraria and some farming/city builder sim mixed in one. It definitely takes a LOT of inspiration from terraria, with many items doing the exact same thing as their terraria counterpart. This is great, I like terraria. However, it fails to capture what truly makes terraria fun and replayable.

Firstly, character movement throughout the world. In the endgame of terraria, you will ride a UFO blasting through the world with infinite explosions - nothing gets in your way. In this game, you can get a good amount of movement speed but... just walk in any direction and you bump into a tree. Or a rock. You can't RUN through the overworld without constantly bumping into things. The game NEEDS to make trees intangible so you can actually move in the overworld uninterrupted.

Speaking of the world, I'm not sure why they hyped up infinite worlds so much. I have currently explored all the biomes in a smallish area around my spawn, faught all the cave bosses, got most of the items. I literally have no reason to ever explore the world infinitely as the content now is just the endgame maps which Ive set up at my homebase. This to me feels like a lack of understanding as to what actually makes games fun - take terraria for example, the game they are inspired by. Terraria doesn't have an infinite world, because it would be pointless after a certain point, and the world it has is filled with everything you need to beat the game. And if you are missing some optional items like a desert pyramid, you would just generate a new world! On top of this, when you reach hardmode in terraria you would constantly revisit old areas to fight the new mobs and mine the new ore, truly utilising the finite world you created. In this game, it's pretty much one and done (maybe they'll make a hardmode in the future?) because you visit a biome once, kill the boss, and theres no reason to really go there again if you got all the drops. In my opinion it should have just been a single, large world with all the biomes and that would have been enough.

Regarding the endgame, I am so BORED. I've done like 4 maps in a row all forcing me to mine 100 or so blocks of ancient ore. WHY. I don't NEED anymore ancient ore, I already have thousands! There's nothing I can do with this ore except sell it! On top of this, there's no super FAST way to blast through these levels, even with bombs, dynamite and a tier 10 pickaxe with a mining trinkets it still takes too long. I was stuck in a map for an uncomfortable amount of time because I missed an ore vein. (if anyone played path of exile 2, do you remember when players complained about this sort of thing, where they almost complete a map but miss one enemy at the beginning of the map and have to backtrack the whole map trying to find the enemy? This is kinda similar). It would be much better if the game was able to select which kind of incursion we want to generate, like a straight up boss arena where you just fight the boss and get rewards, because mining ore to complete the map is getting reaaaal old. The boss fights themselves are kinda fun, even if they are just the same bosses again and again with "number go up".

Even with all the weapons and items, the combat in the game is less complex that you would think. The game has hordes of enemies swarm you. There are weapons that can only attack one single enemy at a time, and weapons with piercing. You pretty much have to use the piercing weapons/spells otherwise you it would take forever to fight all the enemies. Theres even a boss thats a swarm of bats with each bat having its own health bar. GOOD LUCK trying to use a single target weapon. I understand "different sets/tools for different jobs" but in 90% of cases a piercing weapon is the best choice. And also, summons are ok but the ones that can't phase through walls are pretty useless as they have to walk around blocks which means even with a high summon speed they can take forever to pathfind.

So yeah, that's about it. There's some minor stuff as well like how I hardly interacted with the villagers after a certain point, and the music is kinda annoying after a while, and the lighting is not that good. It's way too dark half the time.

My final verdict would be... try it out as a lot of people seem to like it and its quite cheap on sale. But if you played terraria for hundreds of hours, you may feel frustrated with certain aspects and systems here. I think with time it could become great with updates, so maybe I'll check back in the future.

Necesse is missing something in the sauce. It‚Äôs fine. It‚Äôs the white noise of coop terraria/minecraft-likes. It avoids making any huge stumbles and won't piss you off, but fails to really elevate itself meaningfully. What you do in the first hour is more or less what you‚Äôll be doing by the 30th. For $10 I‚Äôd recommend it if you‚Äôre bored. Anything more and you might wonder why you bought something so bland.

The npc sim that is one of the big selling points is‚Ä¶ *fine*. It‚Äôs nice and powerful, sure, but why? Why does it exist? *Oopsie, just because*! They needed to either provide some game design reasons for it to exist (e.g., factory-style; having to actually give giant clumps of resources to your king or something) or to make the npc sim way more personable, like Dragon Quest Builders 2, where the npcs are way more greedy. It‚Äôs not even like Terraria where you‚Äôre trying to figure out how to get npcs to move in or what makes them happy ‚Äî they show up like an unceasing assembly line to your base from the jump.

In Necesse, you can set up 25 3x3 prisons, give the npcs only a diet of raw vegetables, make them work all day long and they‚Äôll be like 95% happy. You‚Äôll probably have this figured out in the first few hours. Whereas in DQB2, the npcs want taverns. They want toilets. They want baths. They want a pool. They want a sauna. They want a castle. They come to you with demands. They want all sorts of things ‚Äî that you can make just as well in Necesse, but there‚Äôs no reason to. Eventually it becomes white noise on a tv screen that you completely ignore.

Combat is fine. There‚Äôs lots of bosses. There‚Äôs a decent amount of weapon variety, but the AI is braindead and lacks any ability to pressure you meaningfully so it ends up not mattering.

Like most games mimicking Terraria, Necesse totally fails to reinvent itself after the first act. Trinkets and mounts and weapons are just not impactful enough. You don‚Äôt transform from the lowly trudging settler into a racing, flying, unstoppable vestige of death. You‚Äôre just the same dude, with a little bit more particle vfx and higher numbers. Monsters similarly ‚Äî they‚Äôre basically all the same walking towards you in clumps that all do the same things.

The art is ugly, even after this redesign. Biomes lack personality. Exploration is flat and boring, there needs to be more POIs and definitely more ore in the walls ‚Äî it‚Äôs way too empty feeling. The ‚ÄúDeep Caves‚Äù which is the quasi-hardmode area is incredibly unfun to explore because of lava being everywhere. It needed to be limited to lava POIs rather than making every biome covered in annoying lava pools.

And that‚Äôs one of the pitfalls of the infinite generated world ‚Äî you never get the sense that you‚Äôre pushing into some exciting new boundary, like in Terraria, or Core Keeper‚Äôs world generation 2.0 re-do. You just explore the same biomes over and over and pray you get some new POI. Even if you do it often doesn‚Äôt have anything terribly interesting or useful.

Enemies don‚Äôt even appear to drop anything useful either ‚Äî all your main weapons and items are either going to be from ores, bosses, or POIs ‚Äî so there‚Äôs no real point to killing anything.

Overall, the game is fine. How much more mid you want in your life is up to you.

I‚Äôve had a good amount of fun with Necesse, especially in the early stages. The settlement-building system is one of the game‚Äôs strongest points ‚Äî it‚Äôs satisfying to recruit NPCs, set up houses, and assign them to different jobs. Having workers take care of farming, crafting, and other tasks gives the world a nice sense of life and progression.

That said, once you get past the early game, the progression starts to feel less rewarding. After a while, it feels like you‚Äôre just moving from boss to boss without much need for mining, crafting, or meaningful exploration in between. The gear upgrades and rewards start to feel less impactful, and the mid-to-late game loop doesn‚Äôt quite capture the same sense of discovery as the beginning.

For the sale price of around $10, Necesse is definitely worth picking up ‚Äî there‚Äôs plenty of charm and solid mechanics to enjoy. But with just the 1.0 content, it left me wanting more. I would argue that most of it is just downright worse but I wouldn't call this a bad game by any means, I did enjoy my time with my friends, but that's not enough for me to warrant a suggestion that others play this game. 

Like terraria the combat loop in this game is mine stuff, build stuff, fight enemies/bosses, repeat. Unlike Terraria the sense of progression in this game is very shallow and there is no real movement going on in the world. The game refuses to change up its rules or alter the gameplay AT ALL in order to shake things up. For the period of literally the entirety of the game it goes as follows:

1. Mine in new area to get ore unique to that biome

2. Build new pickaxe with the aformentioned ore to break be able to break the next biomes blocks

3. Repeat

There are of course bosses unique to each biome and they're alright, kind of easy if I will be honest but I did enjoy the pursuit of trying to kill them all. That desire quickly fades when you realize that the cycle I mentioned before is entirely unchanging and it just becomes a slog. Each new biome is basically a reskin of the last with very minimal differences. There are unique enemies but they're mostly, (but not entirely), the same thing even lacking lots of visual flair to even make them distinctive. The actual tile-sets themselves I think are lackluster but I may be conflating this thought with just how samey the gameplay is between the biomes.

Terraria is not a game I love to death, but it is a game I respect. Each biome/region has such distinctive visual and gameplay differences from each other that it makes you have to change your approach upon entering them. Once you beat Wall of Flesh suddenly hard mode occurs and you are showered with such crazy shit constantly, and the rules change (like corruption spreading) where it switches up your goals. That game forces you to adapt and fight for your goals. Necesse has  at most a minimal amount of that. I was hoping when I unlocked the deep cave ladder that it was basically the "hard mode transition" that Terraria has but nope, it's the same shit but now there is lava in some places. Boring, not entertaining, barely an obstacle.

I think why there isnt a sense of world progression is because Terraria has this problem where people who join a world late in have this feeling of missing out on the events that previously occurred, especially hard mode and on. It does have a linear path to advance the world and once it's been tread that's it. I think the Necesse devs recognized that issue and made Necesse about individual progression rather than a world progression. An interesting idea but they didn't solve more issues than they made, and as a result they made a mediocre experience. This is made more obvious where after mining and upgrading your stuff when you leave the mine everything on the surface is completely trivial in terms of difficulty. That's a shame.

The settlement system is fine but there's really not much to it, it sort of just exists but it's not bad. I'm sure as time goes on they will flesh out that system but I don't have many complaints beyond "needs greater depth and focus."

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

+ Slightly simplified top-down Terraria + simplified Rimworld. The mix of colony management optimization and Terraria-style progression is addicting in every way. If you enjoy anything close to Terraria, this is an instant buy.

+ The soundtrack has its own vibe that's hard to describe. It's good... perhaps fewer epic highs compared to other games, but the overall floor is higher. The first boss' song is an absolute banger... and it's just the first boss.

+ The new seamless world gen is so much nicer than the island style of Early Access. Just a straight upgrade.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- The first and most serious con, and the ultimate tipping point for a negative review, is the Incursion system. For most of the game, you're playing Terraria+Rimworld. Once you complete the "main story" missions, the game turns into an oversimplified Diablo/Path of Exile game. You run tablets (maps/rifts) that have random modifiers to get a few types of currencies. You use these currencies to linearly increase the stats of your existing gear. At the end of the tablets, you fight a boss which is usually poorly balanced and either super under or overpowered relative to your current power level. Rinse and repeat, grind, grind, grind. You can basically ignore your settlement and the rest of the game at this point.

- Difficulty settings feel under-cooked and tacked on. There are no mechanical differences with combat or boss mechanics between the difficulties, only "things hit harder" and "you can't revive settlers if they die." 

- At v1.0.2, there are still quite substantial balancing issues. Oftentimes I would upgrade to a newer weapon that did less damage than the previous one even taking into account AOE/piercing abilities. Some weapons in mid game I ended up keeping until the very end.

- Significant performance issues later on. Running a 13600k and 9070 XT at 1440p and I can't get more than 120 fps (usually bouncing from 80-120) at end game with a single settlement. During the penultimate boss fight, I even dropped to consistently below 60 fps. Max single CPU core usage around 20% which points to optimization issues. This game shouldn't have a problem running at a locked high refresh rate on a weaker system, let alone mine.

- Most of the bosses are... bland and simple, I guess? In Early Access this was forgivable because I expected changes to be made, but every boss boils down to three things: classic worm boss (easy to defeat with piercing weapons to ignore all mechanics), a magic boss that circles around you and shoots projectiles (just circle them back and attack with a homing weapon until you win), or a boss that charges/rams you in a straight line (run in a circle to avoid and attack with a homing weapon until you win). One of the later bosses changes it up slightly by making you play tic-tac-toe against them while also dodging projectiles which was well designed, but it's the only boss with anything interesting going on.

- In addition to the previous point, bosses are also bland in the sense that the fights aren't much of a spectacle, even the final "main story" boss. While this game isn't Terraria, it's probably the best comparison so I'll use it. The first time you fight bosses like the Wall of Flesh, the Empress of Light, Celestial Pillars/Moon Lord, and others feels like an epic war of attrition. Here, there was very little difference between the third wizard and final wizard bosses other than the arena location.

I'm playing co-op with my friend and we're having quite a bit of fun doing it. Having said that, the mechanics/systems get boring pretty fast. Here are some of the negatives:

1- Progression: The gear progression is odd...  At the begining, you gain access to starter tools but quite quickly (and almost at the same time) you unlock copper, iron and gold which allows you to skip the progression of the in-between materials, launching from starter tools to.. well.. gold in no time. I found this disapointing and completely underwhelming. I would have loved a slower progression towards unlocking these better tools. This seems to have robbed me of any sense of achivement regarding said tools. 
2- Biome progression: So far, the world appears to be nothing but the same biomes, stitched together on a wide, open map. I would have loved to see the world become tougher, the biomes changing as I walk away from my start location and run 3000m 5000m, 10,000, away, in a straight line, away from home. Alas, it appears that it's just the same biomes, at the same difficulty, over and over again, no mater how far I make it away from home. The same loot, the same monsters, the same biomes. Seems to me like there is very little reason to spread out and build in any other location other than my start location. The first level of dungeons appears to be the same; the same dungeon biomes, repeated ad nauseam, with the same loot, same monsters, same difficulty, no mater how far I travel. 
3) Gear crafting: Once I found and went into the swamp dungeon, a quick run around allowed me enough material to build an entire armor set. It didn't take much effort; it didn't take very much time, it didn't take any planning. There was no 'working on' this gear progression; it simply happened once I found the right biome. Found the ore, processed it and voila; a brand new armor set with minimal effort. In another hour, I made 3 more, for my settlers.

As much as I enjoy playing this game with my friend, now that I know what I'm doing, I can't see myself playing it for a second playthorugh. It lacks a real sense of progression. It lacks depths. I didn't take long for me to get a 'same old, same old' feeling, when I left my settlement to go on an 'adventure'. Very quickly, any sense of adventure gets replaced with a sense of 'I've seen this 100 times already'. Once you know what you're doing, progression will be absurdly easy and would require very little effort / play time. 

In short, it lacks a ense of biome progression. It lacks a sense of gear progression. It very quickly devolves into a feeling of 'same old' biomes, same old monsters, same old loot. There is very little to ZERO need to spread out and rebuild anywhere. There is no need to build a step up base. There is no need to explore anything other than the biomes that you can already access from the first hour or 2 of playing. 

This game has some good, strong bones. Alas, the implemention seems... off...  After 24+hours of gameplay, the game seems very shallow. It lacks a solid progression system. The sense of adventure quickly wears thin and dissapears almost entirely. Perhaps I just got addicted to the likes of Valheim, where opening a new biome feels exciting; where exploring and maping new island makes me happy; even after 1000+ hours of gametime. 

The Pros:
- Settlement building was fun. Had a great time building our home, building settler homes, building farms, animal pens, roads, chest rooms and so on. The dev did a great job on this! Lots of decorations, building bocks etc. 
- Love the 'cosmetic'  slots that allowed us to wear one armor set while looking like another. Kudos for letting us look how we WANT to look. My friend was super-happy to wear the frog head while I loved rocking purple robes, orange boots and a bone headpiece. Alas, 'metal' progression doesn't really exist so we didn't need to update our settler rooms. They don't seem to care if something is made from wood, copper or gold. We'd love to see a more in depth 'room happiness' mechanic. Of course, this means that the ease of which you can access iron, gold etc would need to be re-tooled. 

- The ability to 'mod' your chacter using trinkets was amazing; From being able to build for mana-regen to extra armor. We loved the ability to tailor our enchants based on our build wants. We spent WAY too much gold re-rolling our enchants :)  but we see this as a positive because this meants that even 24+ hours in, gold still retained value for us. 


-------------
Suggestions: 
- Change the whole map system where you can hit tougher biomes when you travel far away. Give us a reason to build step-up bases; to link bases using mine cart rails. To fight out way through the map to get to other, tougher places. As it stands, there are zero reasons for us to move away from where we started. 

- Need a 'settler leveling' system where we can assign points to our settlers. They can acquire XP from completing certain tasks. IE: Unlock cook recipes the more they cook. Unlock better mage enchants the more they enchant our stuff etc. This would breath new life and new choices into our settlers. Once programmed into their tasks, we had no need to even care that they existed. We have no emtional connection to them; there's no need for us to interact with them other than pay our mage for enchants.

- Would love a skill based leveling system where we become better at mining, farming and so on. Killing countless thousands of monsters, in a game where spawns just keeps comming, holds little to no value. There is no real reason to keep killing monsters. If anything, the goal is to drop 100,000 torches to monsters STOP spawning since mobs don't have any value other than being a general annoyance. 

- Speaking of useless monsters: We'd love to see a "+1% damage to <x> after 100 kills, 1k kills, 10k kills, 25kills, 50k kills (or some such). At the very least, it would give us a small tangible benefit for slauthering mobs and add some goals for a small increase in damage to certain bosses. ;) (example: 10k purple mage kills gives me a 4% extra dam on the mage boos? Heck yeah! Bring on the farming slaughter!) I love such proverbial carrot danglings. They give me purpose, something to strive for.
